headline: President Trump heads to El Paso for first 2020 campaign rally and to push for border wall funding
subHeadline: This comes as the field of Democratic contenders gets even more crowded with the addition of Senators Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Morgan Ortagus, Juan Williams, Kennedy, and Greg. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." The battle for 2020 is officially on as President Trump holds his first campaign rally in El Paso, Texas, tonight, the president taking aim at Democrat Beto O'Rourke for holding a counter rally in the city as he makes his big push for border security.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We're going to El Paso. We have a line that is very long already. I mean, you see what's going on. And I understand our competitors got a line too, but it's a tiny little line. Of course, they'll make it sound like they had more people than we do. That's not going to happen. But we're going there for a reason. We're going there to keep our country safe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This comes as the field of Democratic contenders gets even more crowded. Trump mocking Elizabeth Warren for the DNA debacle hanging over her campaign announcement, the president also poking fun at Senator Amy Klobuchar for announcing her candidacy in a snowstorm. Warren firing back against the president's ancestry attacks.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, D-MASS.
utterances.sentences: By the time we get to 2020, Donald Trump may not even be president.

utterances.speaker: WARREN
utterances.sentences: In fact, he may not even be a free person.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And Klobuchar addressing reports she can't find a campaign manager because she's difficult to work for.

utterances.speaker: SEN. AMY KLOBUCHAR, D-MINN.
utterances.sentences: I am tough. I push people. That is true. But my point is that I have high expectations for myself. I have high expectations for the people that work for me, and I have high expectations for this country.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And Kamala Harris also making some headlines today for this comment.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Have you ever smoked?

utterances.speaker: SEN. KAMALA HARRIS, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: I have.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: And I inhaled. I did inhale.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: It was a long time ago.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Was at a blunt or joint?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: It was a joint.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So if it was legalized all throughout the country in medicinal, would you, you know, do it?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Listen, I think that it gives a lot of people joy and we need more joy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, Greg, we'll get to that in a second. But you and Amy Klobuchar have a lot in common, very difficult to work for.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Exactly. I like her more and more the more I hear about her because she's got the funniest name to say, Klobuchar. You've got 24 hours, Klobuchar, to find the missing kids or you're fired. Anyway, she's got like a 1970's cop show name. Can I just talk about -- and also, it's not sexist to point out that she's got a bad temper. They did that with John McCain, and they did it with Bob Dole, and they do it with Trump. So it ain't sexist. In fact, it's sexist not to do it. Do you have tape of Liz with the kid?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. This is Elizabeth and one of her announcements this weekend.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Get over here, kid. So, here -- this is -- here's the problem with Liz Warren.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Here's the problem with Liz Warren, she's like a professional wrestler who over acts in each scene and then instructs you to believe in the sport no matter what. She is a politician who pretends to be a politician wherever she goes and it's so fake.   And especially in the era of Trump where he rejected all of that -- all of the trimmings of being a politician, he didn't care. It exposes her folly even more as a world-class phony. She's a professional wrestler and you see all the tricks. Grab this kid. And then saying, like, you know, what did she just say? He won't be a free person.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Just say free man.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Save a syllable.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Klobuchar, and we also have Kamala Harris admitting to smoking weed. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: I think it makes her a total hypocrite. I think now, conveniently, she's one of those people who's hopped on board the cannabis caravan. But in reality, people in her state of California have suffered under some of her punitive actions as attorney general. And she even cackled a few years ago when asked about legalization of cannabis in the great state of California. This is someone who has not supported legalization.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, she locked up --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Yeah, she has locked up a bunch of nonviolent offenders and has not lobbied for their release when she absolutely could have. She misused her power. She was horrible on civil rights. And right now, it's just a popularity grab. But who wouldn't cackle with affection, my friend Charlemagne. I thought he was adorable in that clip.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, Juan, you have another reason to vote for Kamala. She smokes grass.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: I think the whole state of California has a reason to vote for her. That's why I think they legalize that. I was telling you guys I was in San Francisco --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: In spite of her, not because of her, in spite of her.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I think -- look, I don't -- by the way, I don't think that was a fair thing that you've said, Kennedy, because, guess what, people --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I know facts are inconvenient. Facts not feelings.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Hang on, please. Enforce the law, that was her job as officer for the State of California. Her job was to enforce the law, not to make it up. And she did it, she enforce the law.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: She did. She selectively enforced laws --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: -- and was horrible on civil --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- selling or using it, I mean, that's the law. She enforced it. But I would say the people who go after her on charges of selective prosecution are way off on this. It's almost to me, and this comes from the left more than the right, they're saying because you're a good prosecutor you can't be a Democrat. How crazy is that?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Well, don't call yourself a progressive prosecutor if your record shows a complete opposite.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I just think she was a very good prosecutor. And I think -- well, anyway, I will leave that up to you. But I will say I think the news today is about Trump in El Paso because our own brain room that you like to cite, Jesse, has said violent crime wasn't higher before the wall in El Paso and --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So glad you brought that up, Juan, because --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I wanted to bring this up because it is such a sham.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, it's not. Here it is. Here are the facts, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you go right ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. In 2009 when the wall was erected in El Paso, oh, 3,300 violent crimes reported. Last available year, statistics were out, 2016, about 2,600 violent crimes reported. That's about a 20 percent drop in violent crime since the wall has been erected in El Paso.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wrong.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, I'm sorry. Not only do you disagree with me. You're disagreeing with the brain room.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This is why I mentioned it because you had played this farcical game before, and so I went to the brain room they said from 6 to 11, '06 to 2011, violent crime went up 17 percent --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Why cherry pick it, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'm not cherry picking. This is what --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, there was no wall in 2006. That's when the money was appropriated, so why stop it at 2011?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You can go all the way. You can go all the way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I did. I went to all the way from when the wall went up until the last available year and crime went down --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Please save Juan from his ridiculous false statements.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- you're wrong and you're trying to fool the audience. But the clear fact is Beto O'Rourke --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You're wrong, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, the Beto O'Rourke, the sheriff in El Paso, the mayor in El Paso says this town had a low crime rate before and after this phony wall.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'll put the stats on my twitter feed and everybody can see the truth. Go ahead, Morgan.

utterances.speaker: MORGAN ORTAGUS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: We're definitely going to solve this argument today, so I'm so glad we're having it. What's interesting to me is that we had more women announce over the weekend, and what we haven't had in the presidential -- I think we have at least five so far that are running. What's happened both on the Democrat side and the Republican side is there's always been one woman on stage. And there have been all of these rules about -- and the senatorial race and presidential races is about how do you approach the one woman on the stage. And now that we have four or five on the stage, it will be interesting to see how the Democrats play that out. How they argue with each other. And so, I actually think it's a really -- it's going to be a really interesting election to see the interaction, especially between the women. Can we just preempt this sort of like catfight narrative that People Magazine and Us Weekly and all these things will put out, these women are going to battle, they're going to be really tough because they're politicians and they want to be the president. And --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And Klobuchar is going to be really tough.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Can I just say one thing about Klobuchar.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I was actually intrigued hearing that she's tough on her staff. I didn't take that as a negative at all.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You're known for being very tough.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Very tough.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, very tough.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I'm practically a dominatrix --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, exactly.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: People pay me for my services.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, the one thing about this whole thing that is so beautiful and why this is going to be the best two years ever, not only do we have a field of Democrat candidates, we have ongoing director's commentary from Donald Trump. This has never happened before. We're going to have a president who is going to do ongoing commentary about everybody. And his media presence is so huge that by comparison, they will seem so small. He'll be Darth Vader. They'll be Ewoks. They'll be Gladys Knight. They'll be the pips.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But that's not the way it played out over the weekend when he went over after Klobuchar as snowman or he says snowwoman. She shot back. Oh, I want to see you stand out in the rain with your hair. I think you dodged --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't know if she said that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, but she said in response in her tweet that he is the one with the sensitive hair. But you know what I think, if he goes after those women, I think they fire back and I don't think that he comes out --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think it's a joke to say -- he goes after everybody. I think we learned that in 2016.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He went after John McCain pretty hard. All right, up next, a radical new Democratic congresswoman sparking bipartisan firestorm for her latest anti-Semitic comments.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.sentences: A radical freshman member of Congress forced to apologize after bipartisan backlash over her anti-Semitic comments. Minnesota Congressman Ilhan Omar under fire, including from top leaders of her own party over a new round of controversial tweets, Omar accused a prominent group, the American-Israel public affairs committee, of paying members of Congress to support Israel. The freshman lawmaker released a statement saying that she, quote, unequivocally apologizes, but then went on to call a (INAUDIBLE) lobby, quote, "problematic." We have seen a lot happened today, Kennedy. Last night, Chelsea Clinton was the only prominent Democrat to come out today -- today we did see Pelosi issue a statement. Other Democrats issued statement condemning these remarks. And of course, she apologized. My question is she sits on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, is this enough? Should she be on that committee or does the apology and the condemnation is that just put a pretty little bow on it?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: No, I think all bets are off. It depends. If this is a political ally and you have to defend her behavior, but I don't think it's OK. I don't think it's OK what Ralph Northam did. I don't think it's OK in this situation. I don't appreciate people not understanding the racist roots of the thing that they mock and not fully grasping it. So, I don't appreciate her being an anti-Semite. And I think antisemitism is a huge problem right. It's something that is really being, sort of, swept under the carpet by the left and, you know, there are people within the movement who have said pretty atrocious things and, you know, dehumanized Jewish people as a whole.  And I think when we start to get into that territory because -- if you take something that a Republican or another person you disagree with out of context and say this is racist, then you have to apply the same metric. And if we do that from everyone and have the exact same purity metric, it's going to be very difficult.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.sentences: Juan, so Kennedy brings up good points. There's actually a piece by Bret Stevens in the New York Times called the progressive assault on Israel, and I challenge everyone to read it. And Bret went through a piece by piece at a LGBTQ task force conference where they were chanting, from the river to the sea, which many people knows means, you know, no state of Israel. He went through how Booker, Warren, Harris, all tried to block anti-BDS legislation in the Senate, and I thought it was a pretty convincing case. And I know that we've talked about this quite a bit on THE FIVE where you see anti-Zionism and anti-Semitism that has taken root in somewhat mainstream policies on the left. Do you agree with that or where do you think your party stance on Israel?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, I think the party is very supportive of Israel, there's no question about that. I think what's going on here is you have people who are -- in the case of Representative Tlaib from Michigan, but also Omar from Minnesota, you have people who are coming in who for the first time are giving voice to people who oppose Israel's policy with regard to Palestinian. I think Tlaib is the first Palestinian woman, someone with Palestinian heritage to be elected to the Congress. And so --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.sentences: The first woman. I think there's been other men.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. And so the point is here that from their perspective, they are trying to criticize Israeli policy and U.S. support for Israeli policies.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.sentences: So you don't think --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What she said was offensive because then she played into the whole meme about Jewish people having money that influences politicians, and that's what she apologized for. But I think you have lots of people, including Kevin McCarthy, now the minority leader in the House who or jumping on this because they see this as a way to potentially divide Democrats. I hope it's not the case. And I think it's evidence that -- of good faith that you have people like Pelosi saying what this congresswoman did was wrong.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.sentences: What do you think, Jesse? Is it political?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, of course, everything is political. I think Pelosi is that one with the problem. If you think about it she had, you know, freshman female come in trafficking anti-Semitism. Freshman female come in and say impeach the M and F'er. And then another freshman female come in and unveil a green new deal which is basically a joke Republicans are now going run against. And if you also look someone didn't even see this headline, Maxine Waters hit with three new ethics violations and she's supposed to be running House Financial Services. Pelosi has come in and done what? Besides shut the government down? Not much.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.sentences: Well, everything if you ask Hillary Clinton.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. I mean, listen, I don't think Pelosi has got a great track record here and this Omar person is just not ready for prime time. She's not polished enough. She's accused someone of blackmailing sexually a senator. She said horrible things about the Covington boys and she's about to get sued for that. And she's called Israel evil, so she's a big problem.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.sentences: Greg, to Jesse's point though, Jewish leaders in her district did sit her down and talk to her about this. She's apparently had a lot of counseling, yet she still tweets these anti-Semitic things.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm always, as I say, somebody apologize, I accept the apology, so I accept the apology. The tweet about the Benjamins was a problem not for the actual -- just the tweet, but it was in the context of things when you described Jews as hypnotic conspirators. That's kind of a bigger issue than the Benjamins thing. The bottom line is there's a lot of countries in the Middle East and one isn't Muslim and that's the one she doesn't like. So we have to ask ourselves, is this a form of bigotry? I think she apologizes, so that's a step. But you know who tweeted support for her? David Duke. So if I were to do what a liberal does and employed guilt by association, the Democrats are now the party of Sarsour, Farrakhan, Omar, and Duke.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.sentences: Well, that takes effort. OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Really, that's pretty easy. I just did it.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.sentences: Virginia Governor Ralph Northam doubles down and refuses to resign. Up next, the bizarre interview he gave to make his case.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The political crisis in Virginia continuing. Governor Ralph Northam however says he's not going anywhere. The embattled Democrat who is resisting calls to step down over a racist yearbook photo says he believe he can help his state heal.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: What have you learned that you didn't know before?

utterances.speaker: GOV. RALPH NORTHAM, D-VA.
utterances.sentences: Well, several things. Starting with I was born in white privilege and that has implications to it. I've also learned why the use of blackface is so offensive. I have thought about resigning but I've also thought about what Virginia needs right now. Right now, Virginia needs someone that can heal. There's no better person to do that than a doctor.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Northam also addressing why he walked back his initial apology.

utterances.speaker: NORTHAM
utterances.sentences: I definitely overreacted. And, again --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: But why did you do that?

utterances.speaker: NORTHAM
utterances.sentences: Well, when you're in a state of shock like I was, we don't always think as clearly as we should. As I've said, I know it's not me in the clan outfit and I started looking in the picture of the individual with blackface and I said that's not me either.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Were you thinking about showing off your moonwalking skills?

utterances.speaker: NORTHAM
utterances.sentences: No, because I don't have those at age 59. But I will tell you, Gayle, I regret that. This is a serious moment.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It's very serious.

utterances.speaker: NORTHAM
utterances.sentences: Whether it was a nervous laugh or whatever, it was inappropriate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile, a Virginia lawmakers plan to impeach Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax now on hold. This comes after a second woman came forward to accuse Fairfax of sexual assault. Fairfax is now calling on the FBI to investigate both of the claims being made against him. Kennedy, I saw you saying you don't believe the governor.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I don't believe the governor when he says, you know -- he's trying to excuse it using a term that Greg appropriately calls virtue signaling. And all he's trying to do is take a, you know, fantastical phrase from the left and apply it here like a band aid, and I think there's much more beneath the surface. And I applaud Gayle King for trying to get to the truth of his motivation. I think Northam looks at Brett Kavanaugh, and even the president, who are much more unapologetic than politicians were -- you know, maybe three years ago, and certainly some in the current climate like Al Franken who must be looking at all this and saying I wish I had just stuck around because if you're the last man standing you get to keep your job. I think he's also looking at Justin Fairfax. And, you know, when you weigh these two cases, the charges against Fairfax are incredibly serious and damning. He's had even more staffers quit over the episode which has now been compounded by a second accuser coming forward and saying that he sexually assaulted yet another woman.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, Jesse, Kennedy doesn't buy this white privilege business. He said he's 59 years old. Obviously, grew up on the eastern shore of Virginia. I wonder what you think.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I thought she blew the interview. It was soft. It was a rehab interview. Why didn't she ask him, if it wasn't you, why did you put the picture on your yearbook page? I mean, it's an easy question. I don't know why she didn't ask that.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: It's hard.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, I'll call Gayle --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Do you guys still talk?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, not as much as we used to.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There was an interesting poll that showed black Virginians were more willing to forgive than white Virginians. And I thought why don't we have a man on the street person to go down to Virginia and ask these questions? I can't think of a better person to go. But --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You mean you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Why would you say that, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You're the man on the street.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We're not paying for your vacation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Someone should go down to Virginia and ask people what they think.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But in the summertime.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, when the --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- in D.C. Here's what the Democrats have done though, they have given the biggest political gift to Republicans. They have doubled down on a double blackface scandal and a double sexual assault allegation scandal. So now any time anything happens, Republicans get two get-out-of-jail-free cards, and any Republican commentator gets two talking points.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow. This was all about you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, but usually it is. But in all seriousness, Juan, you guys are killing yourselves with this thing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right, OK. So, Morgan, what about Fairfax?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So you now have his staff, as Kennedy was saying, apparently leaving in large numbers, I think he's left with two people. And over the weekend, he's saying just give me my due process, which I think was the last thing we heard from Kavanagh.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.sentences: Well, I agree with him and I think this is one of the tragedies of politicizing Me Too. And that whole movement that started as speaking, you know, with men who are in power and using that power over women. It was this movement that had nothing to do with politics. It got politicized during Kavanaugh, and the problem is that we never finished having the national conversation about how do you hear women and believe their stories, but at the same time give the guys the due process they deserve or, you know, turn around it could be either gender. And I think that's a big tragedy of all of this is you either zero-tolerance or you're not. And what is the fair process for giving someone, you know, the benefit of the doubt, of giving them due process? I would say the other reason why this has been just a catastrophe, the way it's been handled in Virginia is because of the top three and there's an election in November. And Republicans hold at least one or two seats in both the House and the Senate majority. It's going to be a contentious election. If it wasn't election and wasn't all three top policy makers, you would probably see a bit of a different reaction.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And you also know Fairfax. How does this play into it?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.sentences: I think if this happens to a lot of us who people who knew Kavanaugh and those of us -- my husband and I know Justin, and you see someone who's in the public light and something happens to them, and it's so different from the person that you've known. And that's why it doesn't matter if you're a Republican or if you're a Democrat, or whatever your political philosophy is. There is racism, sexism in America and around the world. And when you politicize this stuff, when you politicize Kavanaugh in order not to get a Supreme Court, it just ends up hurting everybody in the process.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: And that's why Republicans warn Democrats about.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS,
utterances.sentences: OK. So, let me go to our poll expert.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Thank you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Because I think you have some very interesting numbers to share.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't have any numbers. How dare you set me up like that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh! My God. You set me up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I want to say. I have a theory and I want to ask you here, but first, the definition of a hack is somebody who demands due process for the person on their side but doesn't demand it for the person on the other side. utterances.utterance: Exactly. I like her more and more the more I hear about her because she's got the funniest name to say, Klobuchar. You've got 24 hours, Klobuchar, to find the missing kids or you're fired. Anyway, she's got like a 1970's cop show name. Can I just talk about -- and also, it's not sexist to point out that she's got a bad temper. They did that with John McCain, and they did it with Bob Dole, and they do it with Trump. So it ain't sexist. In fact, it's sexist not to do it. Do you have tape of Liz with the kid?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes. This is Elizabeth and one of her announcements this weekend.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Get over here, kid. So, here -- this is -- here's the problem with Liz Warren.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Here's the problem with Liz Warren, she's like a professional wrestler who over acts in each scene and then instructs you to believe in the sport no matter what. She is a politician who pretends to be a politician wherever she goes and it's so fake. And especially in the era of Trump where he rejected all of that -- all of the trimmings of being a politician, he didn't care. It exposes her folly even more as a world-class phony. She's a professional wrestler and you see all the tricks. Grab this kid. And then saying, like, you know, what did she just say? He won't be a free person.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Just say free man.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Save a syllable.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Klobuchar, and we also have Kamala Harris admitting to smoking weed. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I think it makes her a total hypocrite. I think now, conveniently, she's one of those people who's hopped on board the cannabis caravan. But in reality, people in her state of California have suffered under some of her punitive actions as attorney general. And she even cackled a few years ago when asked about legalization of cannabis in the great state of California. This is someone who has not supported legalization.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, she locked up --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yeah, she has locked up a bunch of nonviolent offenders and has not lobbied for their release when she absolutely could have. She misused her power. She was horrible on civil rights. And right now, it's just a popularity grab. But who wouldn't cackle with affection, my friend Charlemagne. I thought he was adorable in that clip.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, Juan, you have another reason to vote for Kamala. She smokes grass.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I think the whole state of California has a reason to vote for her. That's why I think they legalize that. I was telling you guys I was in San Francisco --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: In spite of her, not because of her, in spite of her.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I think -- look, I don't -- by the way, I don't think that was a fair thing that you've said, Kennedy, because, guess what, people --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I know facts are inconvenient. Facts not feelings.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Hang on, please. Enforce the law, that was her job as officer for the State of California. Her job was to enforce the law, not to make it up. And she did it, she enforce the law.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: She did. She selectively enforced laws --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: -- and was horrible on civil --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- selling or using it, I mean, that's the law. She enforced it. But I would say the people who go after her on charges of selective prosecution are way off on this. It's almost to me, and this comes from the left more than the right, they're saying because you're a good prosecutor you can't be a Democrat. How crazy is that?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Well, don't call yourself a progressive prosecutor if your record shows a complete opposite.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I just think she was a very good prosecutor. And I think -- well, anyway, I will leave that up to you. But I will say I think the news today is about Trump in El Paso because our own brain room that you like to cite, Jesse, has said violent crime wasn't higher before the wall in El Paso and --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So glad you brought that up, Juan, because --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I wanted to bring this up because it is such a sham.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, it's not. Here it is. Here are the facts, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you go right ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. In 2009 when the wall was erected in El Paso, oh, 3,300 violent crimes reported. Last available year, statistics were out, 2016, about 2,600 violent crimes reported. That's about a 20 percent drop in violent crime since the wall has been erected in El Paso.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wrong.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, I'm sorry. Not only do you disagree with me. You're disagreeing with the brain room.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is why I mentioned it because you had played this farcical game before, and so I went to the brain room they said from 6 to 11, '06 to 2011, violent crime went up 17 percent --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Why cherry pick it, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm not cherry picking. This is what --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, there was no wall in 2006. That's when the money was appropriated, so why stop it at 2011?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You can go all the way. You can go all the way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I did. I went to all the way from when the wall went up until the last available year and crime went down --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Please save Juan from his ridiculous false statements.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- you're wrong and you're trying to fool the audience. But the clear fact is Beto O'Rourke --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're wrong, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, the Beto O'Rourke, the sheriff in El Paso, the mayor in El Paso says this town had a low crime rate before and after this phony wall.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'll put the stats on my twitter feed and everybody can see the truth. Go ahead, Morgan.

utterances.speaker: MORGAN ORTAGUS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: We're definitely going to solve this argument today, so I'm so glad we're having it. What's interesting to me is that we had more women announce over the weekend, and what we haven't had in the presidential -- I think we have at least five so far that are running. What's happened both on the Democrat side and the Republican side is there's always been one woman on stage. And there have been all of these rules about -- and the senatorial race and presidential races is about how do you approach the one woman on the stage. And now that we have four or five on the stage, it will be interesting to see how the Democrats play that out. How they argue with each other. And so, I actually think it's a really -- it's going to be a really interesting election to see the interaction, especially between the women. Can we just preempt this sort of like catfight narrative that People Magazine and Us Weekly and all these things will put out, these women are going to battle, they're going to be really tough because they're politicians and they want to be the president. And --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Klobuchar is going to be really tough.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Can I just say one thing about Klobuchar.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I was actually intrigued hearing that she's tough on her staff. I didn't take that as a negative at all.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're known for being very tough.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Very tough.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, very tough.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I'm practically a dominatrix --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, exactly.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: People pay me for my services.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, the one thing about this whole thing that is so beautiful and why this is going to be the best two years ever, not only do we have a field of Democrat candidates, we have ongoing director's commentary from Donald Trump. This has never happened before. We're going to have a president who is going to do ongoing commentary about everybody. And his media presence is so huge that by comparison, they will seem so small. He'll be Darth Vader. They'll be Ewoks. They'll be Gladys Knight. They'll be the pips.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But that's not the way it played out over the weekend when he went over after Klobuchar as snowman or he says snowwoman. She shot back. Oh, I want to see you stand out in the rain with your hair. I think you dodged --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know if she said that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, but she said in response in her tweet that he is the one with the sensitive hair. But you know what I think, if he goes after those women, I think they fire back and I don't think that he comes out --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think it's a joke to say -- he goes after everybody. I think we learned that in 2016.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He went after John McCain pretty hard. All right, up next, a radical new Democratic congresswoman sparking bipartisan firestorm for her latest anti-Semitic comments.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: A radical freshman member of Congress forced to apologize after bipartisan backlash over her anti-Semitic comments. Minnesota Congressman Ilhan Omar under fire, including from top leaders of her own party over a new round of controversial tweets, Omar accused a prominent group, the American-Israel public affairs committee, of paying members of Congress to support Israel. The freshman lawmaker released a statement saying that she, quote, unequivocally apologizes, but then went on to call a (INAUDIBLE) lobby, quote, "problematic." We have seen a lot happened today, Kennedy. Last night, Chelsea Clinton was the only prominent Democrat to come out today -- today we did see Pelosi issue a statement. Other Democrats issued statement condemning these remarks. And of course, she apologized. My question is she sits on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, is this enough? Should she be on that committee or does the apology and the condemnation is that just put a pretty little bow on it?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: No, I think all bets are off. It depends. If this is a political ally and you have to defend her behavior, but I don't think it's OK. I don't think it's OK what Ralph Northam did. I don't think it's OK in this situation. I don't appreciate people not understanding the racist roots of the thing that they mock and not fully grasping it. So, I don't appreciate her being an anti-Semite. And I think antisemitism is a huge problem right. It's something that is really being, sort of, swept under the carpet by the left and, you know, there are people within the movement who have said pretty atrocious things and, you know, dehumanized Jewish people as a whole. And I think when we start to get into that territory because -- if you take something that a Republican or another person you disagree with out of context and say this is racist, then you have to apply the same metric. And if we do that from everyone and have the exact same purity metric, it's going to be very difficult.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Juan, so Kennedy brings up good points. There's actually a piece by Bret Stevens in the New York Times called the progressive assault on Israel, and I challenge everyone to read it. And Bret went through a piece by piece at a LGBTQ task force conference where they were chanting, from the river to the sea, which many people knows means, you know, no state of Israel. He went through how Booker, Warren, Harris, all tried to block anti-BDS legislation in the Senate, and I thought it was a pretty convincing case. And I know that we've talked about this quite a bit on THE FIVE where you see anti-Zionism and anti-Semitism that has taken root in somewhat mainstream policies on the left. Do you agree with that or where do you think your party stance on Israel?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I think the party is very supportive of Israel, there's no question about that. I think what's going on here is you have people who are -- in the case of Representative Tlaib from Michigan, but also Omar from Minnesota, you have people who are coming in who for the first time are giving voice to people who oppose Israel's policy with regard to Palestinian. I think Tlaib is the first Palestinian woman, someone with Palestinian heritage to be elected to the Congress. And so --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: The first woman. I think there's been other men.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. And so the point is here that from their perspective, they are trying to criticize Israeli policy and U.S. support for Israeli policies.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: So you don't think --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What she said was offensive because then she played into the whole meme about Jewish people having money that influences politicians, and that's what she apologized for. But I think you have lots of people, including Kevin McCarthy, now the minority leader in the House who or jumping on this because they see this as a way to potentially divide Democrats. I hope it's not the case. And I think it's evidence that -- of good faith that you have people like Pelosi saying what this congresswoman did was wrong.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: What do you think, Jesse? Is it political?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, of course, everything is political. I think Pelosi is that one with the problem. If you think about it she had, you know, freshman female come in trafficking anti-Semitism. Freshman female come in and say impeach the M and F'er. And then another freshman female come in and unveil a green new deal which is basically a joke Republicans are now going run against. And if you also look someone didn't even see this headline, Maxine Waters hit with three new ethics violations and she's supposed to be running House Financial Services. Pelosi has come in and done what? Besides shut the government down? Not much.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Well, everything if you ask Hillary Clinton.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. I mean, listen, I don't think Pelosi has got a great track record here and this Omar person is just not ready for prime time. She's not polished enough. She's accused someone of blackmailing sexually a senator. She said horrible things about the Covington boys and she's about to get sued for that. And she's called Israel evil, so she's a big problem.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Greg, to Jesse's point though, Jewish leaders in her district did sit her down and talk to her about this. She's apparently had a lot of counseling, yet she still tweets these anti-Semitic things.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm always, as I say, somebody apologize, I accept the apology, so I accept the apology. The tweet about the Benjamins was a problem not for the actual -- just the tweet, but it was in the context of things when you described Jews as hypnotic conspirators. That's kind of a bigger issue than the Benjamins thing. The bottom line is there's a lot of countries in the Middle East and one isn't Muslim and that's the one she doesn't like. So we have to ask ourselves, is this a form of bigotry? I think she apologizes, so that's a step. But you know who tweeted support for her? David Duke. So if I were to do what a liberal does and employed guilt by association, the Democrats are now the party of Sarsour, Farrakhan, Omar, and Duke.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Well, that takes effort. OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Really, that's pretty easy. I just did it.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Virginia Governor Ralph Northam doubles down and refuses to resign. Up next, the bizarre interview he gave to make his case.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The political crisis in Virginia continuing. Governor Ralph Northam however says he's not going anywhere. The embattled Democrat who is resisting calls to step down over a racist yearbook photo says he believe he can help his state heal.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: What have you learned that you didn't know before?

utterances.speaker: GOV. RALPH NORTHAM, D-VA.
utterances.utterance: Well, several things. Starting with I was born in white privilege and that has implications to it. I've also learned why the use of blackface is so offensive. I have thought about resigning but I've also thought about what Virginia needs right now. Right now, Virginia needs someone that can heal. There's no better person to do that than a doctor.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Northam also addressing why he walked back his initial apology.

utterances.speaker: NORTHAM
utterances.utterance: I definitely overreacted. And, again --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: But why did you do that?

utterances.speaker: NORTHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, when you're in a state of shock like I was, we don't always think as clearly as we should. As I've said, I know it's not me in the clan outfit and I started looking in the picture of the individual with blackface and I said that's not me either.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Were you thinking about showing off your moonwalking skills?

utterances.speaker: NORTHAM
utterances.utterance: No, because I don't have those at age 59. But I will tell you, Gayle, I regret that. This is a serious moment.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: It's very serious.

utterances.speaker: NORTHAM
utterances.utterance: Whether it was a nervous laugh or whatever, it was inappropriate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, a Virginia lawmakers plan to impeach Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax now on hold. This comes after a second woman came forward to accuse Fairfax of sexual assault. Fairfax is now calling on the FBI to investigate both of the claims being made against him. Kennedy, I saw you saying you don't believe the governor.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I don't believe the governor when he says, you know -- he's trying to excuse it using a term that Greg appropriately calls virtue signaling. And all he's trying to do is take a, you know, fantastical phrase from the left and apply it here like a band aid, and I think there's much more beneath the surface. And I applaud Gayle King for trying to get to the truth of his motivation. I think Northam looks at Brett Kavanaugh, and even the president, who are much more unapologetic than politicians were -- you know, maybe three years ago, and certainly some in the current climate like Al Franken who must be looking at all this and saying I wish I had just stuck around because if you're the last man standing you get to keep your job. I think he's also looking at Justin Fairfax. And, you know, when you weigh these two cases, the charges against Fairfax are incredibly serious and damning. He's had even more staffers quit over the episode which has now been compounded by a second accuser coming forward and saying that he sexually assaulted yet another woman.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Jesse, Kennedy doesn't buy this white privilege business. He said he's 59 years old. Obviously, grew up on the eastern shore of Virginia. I wonder what you think.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I thought she blew the interview. It was soft. It was a rehab interview. Why didn't she ask him, if it wasn't you, why did you put the picture on your yearbook page? I mean, it's an easy question. I don't know why she didn't ask that.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It's hard.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I'll call Gayle --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do you guys still talk?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, not as much as we used to.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There was an interesting poll that showed black Virginians were more willing to forgive than white Virginians. And I thought why don't we have a man on the street person to go down to Virginia and ask these questions? I can't think of a better person to go. But --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You mean you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Why would you say that, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You're the man on the street.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We're not paying for your vacation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Someone should go down to Virginia and ask people what they think.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But in the summertime.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, when the --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- in D.C. Here's what the Democrats have done though, they have given the biggest political gift to Republicans. They have doubled down on a double blackface scandal and a double sexual assault allegation scandal. So now any time anything happens, Republicans get two get-out-of-jail-free cards, and any Republican commentator gets two talking points.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. This was all about you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, but usually it is. But in all seriousness, Juan, you guys are killing yourselves with this thing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right, OK. So, Morgan, what about Fairfax?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So you now have his staff, as Kennedy was saying, apparently leaving in large numbers, I think he's left with two people. And over the weekend, he's saying just give me my due process, which I think was the last thing we heard from Kavanagh.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Well, I agree with him and I think this is one of the tragedies of politicizing Me Too. And that whole movement that started as speaking, you know, with men who are in power and using that power over women. It was this movement that had nothing to do with politics. It got politicized during Kavanaugh, and the problem is that we never finished having the national conversation about how do you hear women and believe their stories, but at the same time give the guys the due process they deserve or, you know, turn around it could be either gender. And I think that's a big tragedy of all of this is you either zero-tolerance or you're not. And what is the fair process for giving someone, you know, the benefit of the doubt, of giving them due process? I would say the other reason why this has been just a catastrophe, the way it's been handled in Virginia is because of the top three and there's an election in November. And Republicans hold at least one or two seats in both the House and the Senate majority. It's going to be a contentious election. If it wasn't election and wasn't all three top policy makers, you would probably see a bit of a different reaction.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And you also know Fairfax. How does this play into it?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I think if this happens to a lot of us who people who knew Kavanaugh and those of us -- my husband and I know Justin, and you see someone who's in the public light and something happens to them, and it's so different from the person that you've known. And that's why it doesn't matter if you're a Republican or if you're a Democrat, or whatever your political philosophy is. There is racism, sexism in America and around the world. And when you politicize this stuff, when you politicize Kavanaugh in order not to get a Supreme Court, it just ends up hurting everybody in the process.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: And that's why Republicans warn Democrats about.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS,
utterances.utterance: OK. So, let me go to our poll expert.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Thank you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because I think you have some very interesting numbers to share.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't have any numbers. How dare you set me up like that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh! My God. You set me up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I want to say. I have a theory and I want to ask you here, but first, the definition of a hack is somebody who demands due process for the person on their side but doesn't demand it for the person on the other side. So, if you were demanding due process for Kavanaugh, you owe it to Fairfax as well. I think that's - I think the governor. You can't tell whether he's digging in or digging his own grave. It's hard to tell. He said that being a doctor, he can bring Virginia to the next level, is the next level Grand Wizard, because I don't know he's two parts stupid and one part dumb. Anyway, so here's my theory.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, the higher - what Jesse brought up. The higher percentage of blacks favor him staying in over a percentage of whites. So, why is that? Is it because whites have to virtue signal in public and say, he's got to resign, but blacks don't? Do you follow me?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I've got you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But what I think is in fact that black people having lived through the history of racism in this country will say, you know what, it's possible to forgive and guess what his record as governor is actually pretty good on that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I find that interesting. I find that the forgiveness is higher. I think people can learn from that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it's true. I just don't know if it's good Greg, because I think sometimes people you know it's like a child who gets abused or whatever, you're always saying you know my parents really are good people and it's going to be all right. What are you going to say?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. But you also mentioned his policies, they might be looking at his policies too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I agree. I think they are looking at his policy. All right. A new bombshell in the heated battle between billionaire Jeff Bezos and the National Enquirer. You've got to see this stuff and you can only see it here on "The Five," next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What did he say?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Breakdown. National Enquirer firing back against allegations of blackmail and extortion. From Amazon billionaire Jeff Bezos, this comes after the Amazon founder claim the magazine threatened to publish explicit photos of him and his mistress. If he didn't stop investigating, have the tabloid got his private text messages. The attorney for Enquirer's CEO saying, they did nothing wrong.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It absolutely is not extortion and not blackmail. What happened was that the story was given to the National Enquirer by a reliable source that had given information to the National Enquirer for seven years prior to this story. It was a source that was well-known to both Mr. Bezos and Mr. Sanchez.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Oh! the Enquirer also wanted Bezos to publicly say that its reporting was not politically motivated. Now meanwhile, a bombshell new report says the anonymous source of the leaked texts and pictures to the tabloid is in fact Michael Santos, the brother of Bezos girlfriend Lauren Sanchez. So, Greg what stands out to you most in this story.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a dirty Sanchez.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: You have to pick a side here. You're either Team Bezos or pro Pecker. David Pecker is the CEO --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is a difficult story for an infantile humorist like myself in which every avenue gives an opportunity. The guy's name is Sanchez.
